content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'm accepting this one because Manhattan distance is something cool to compute, moreover, a lot of clashes are easy to get, this one will add some spices :)
I was close to approving it, but I think it's too hard for reverse. I like it otherwise.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very cool! perfect for an oneliner
Love it, but would not approve for Reverse

I would have approved if if wasn't for the Reverse mode. I think it is way too complicated to deduce the relation between several number strings such as
312 123 321
321 312 123
and 
396.
The only informative test is the first
0 0
2 2
as even the second is a bit obscure.
It seems way too hard to understand the goal with variable length entry and only one clear test

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This contribution meets all the criteria to be validated! It can be done in 5 minutes and is adapted to the shortest mode
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Thank you for your advice, i modified statement.

Consider simplifying the introduction a little - here's a less verbose description:

**Introduction**:
The "Manhattan Distance" is the distance between two points in an N dimensional space. In simple terms, it is the sum of absolute differences between the measures in all dimensions of two points.

2D Example:
Point1: (x1, y1)  Point2: (x2, y2)  Manhattan Distance: |x1-x2| + |y1-y2|;

3D Example:
Point1: (x1, y1, z1)  Point2: (x2, y2, z2)  Manhattan Distance: |x1-x2| + |y1-y2| + |z1-z2|

**Challenge**:
Given two points A and B, calculate the Manhattan Distance between them.
Easy to access and well explained. The statement should be a little more airy.
maybe it would help if there was a small numerical example in the introduction

Using cityblock
```python
from scipy.spatial.distance import cityblock
n = int(input())
print(cityblock([int(i) for i in input().split()], [int(i) for i in input().split()]))
```

Goal section
* Please change "difference" to "differences".

Input section
* Please change "the dimension" to "the number of dimensions".
* Please change "coordinate" to "coordinates".
* Please delete "on [[N]] dimension".

Constraints section
* The maximum N tested is way smaller than 100. I think you may reduce it to 10.

Test cases/validators
* There is just one case where negative numbers are tested. Suggest you to modify the inputs to include more negative numbers.
* Suggest you to modify one test case and one validator to increase the number of dimensions tested (e.g. 9 or 10).

Thanks.
Thanks for watching! i think it would be funny if the mode is Reverse.

It would certainly be funny, but I would discourage reverse for this particular puzzle since the pattern isn't so obvious, and it'll only gives experienced clashers an advantage (i.e. unfair to new clashers).
Thank you for your advice! about the test cases, i made only minor changes considering the reverse mode.

I think I would write it in simpler terms : 
"it is the sum of absolute differences between each coordinate of two points"

Also I would change
The "Manhattan Distance" is the distance between...
to
The "Manhattan Distance" is a distance between...

as there are many distances that could be defined on N dimensional space.
